solution.text:
Given that :
No. of students applied from III-Year = _{i}_
No. of students applied from II-Year = _{j}_
No. of students applied from I-Year = _{k}_
Total No. of the student applied = _{i}_+_{j}_+_{k}_
Total No. of the student applied = _{{i+j+k}}_
Now,
Possibilities that a III-Year's name will be chosen E(III) = 3\(\times\)_{i}_
i.e., E(III) = _{{3*i}}_
Similarly,
E(II) = _{{2*j}}_
E(I) = _{{1*k}}_
So, total possibilities:
i.e., E(T) = E(II)+E(II)+E(I)
i.e., E(T) = _{{3*i}}_+_{{2*j}}_+_{{1*k}}_
i.e., E(T) = _{{(3*i)+(2*j)+(1*k)}}_
hence,
Possibilities that a III-Year's name will be chosen
P(III) = \(E(III)\over E(T)\)
P(III) = \(_{{3*i}}_\over _{{(3*i)+(2*j)+(1*k)}}_\)
P(III) = _{{trunc((3*i)/((3*i)+(2*Decimal(j))+(1*k)),5)}}_

content.text:
A special lottery is to be held to select a student who will live in the only deluxe room in a hostel. There are _{i}_ III-Year, _{j}_ II-Year and _{k}_ I-Year students who applied.
Each III-Year's name is placed in the lottery 3 times; each II-Year's name, 2 times and I-Year's name, 1 time. What is the probability that a III-Year's name will be chosen?
